subject: Re: [junit] Re: How to enable/disable JUnit tests programatically ?
msgSnippet: You could just use the code as a template.  The major concept in the code is the notion of a filter, that responds to annotations. I see no reason why someone
messageBody:
You could just use the code as a template. The major concept in the code is
the notion of a filter, that responds to annotations.

I see no reason why someone could not marry the two possibilities.

On Thu, May 28, 2009 at 10:40 AM, mortench2004 <mortench2004@...>wrote:

> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Mike Forsberg <bigmike@...> wrote:
> >
> > I needed the same thing and looked at the junit ext projectï¿½ but found
> their
> > implementation a little "weird".
> >
> > So in my free time, I implemented a configurable test filter based on
> system
> > properties. It can be found at http://github.com/bigmikef/junit-addons/
> .
>
> Thanks, the only problem is that your solution require me to use a specific
> runner. Once I do that I am unable to configure other runners like
> "@RunWith(Parameterized.class)" which I also need to use.
>
> This is really a problem with the design of JUnit4. and not your filter
> (Spring has the same problem due to the Junit4 RunWith limitations). IMO
> this aspect of JUnit should be completely redesigned.
